awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: A major leap forward: Optimal designs for correlated data, multiple objectives, and multiple covariates
awd_abstract_narration:
Designed experiments form an integral part of the scientific process in many areas of research, such as the biological sciences, the health sciences, the social sciences, engineering, marketing, education, and others. A well-chosen design facilitates the collection of data that maximizes the information for the scientific questions of interest at a fixed cost, or that minimizes the cost for a desired level of information. Many experiments deal with correlated data, multiple objectives, or multiple covariates, but little is known about the identification of good designs in such settings. This project establishes how to find efficient designs for these types of problems for the most commonly used statistical models. The tools developed in this project have a tremendous potential for impact on society because designed experiments are used so often to further knowledge in many different fields. Results from the project will be made available to researchers in other areas through easy-to-use software that implements algorithms that are developed. Graduate students will be trained to become researchers in design of experiments. 

The outcomes of this project constitute a major leap forward in understanding and knowledge of optimal design of experiments. Recent contributions by the principal investigators and others have had a significant impact on the advancement of optimal design of experiments for nonlinear and generalized linear models. However, these results have for the most part been limited to (i) independent data; (ii) use of a single optimality criterion; and (iii) use of a single covariate. While these results are arguably important in their own right, this project will extend methods and tools to problems with correlated data, multiple objectives, and multiple covariates. The latter could consist of a mix of covariates that can be chosen by the experimenter and covariates that, known or unknown at the design stage, cannot be controlled by the experimenter. Preliminary results indicate that this is an opportune time to make these challenging but critical steps. Building a framework for deriving and identifying optimal designs for these types of problems will provide a much needed addition to our collective design toolbox. Current results are very sparse and only for very specialized problems that are mostly motivated by mathematical feasibility. The project develops tools to select efficient designs for models and conditions that are far more realistic than those that have been considered so far.

por.por_cntn:
Designed experiments are an integral part of the scientific process. They are critically important in almost all areas of science to learn about cause and effect relationships between variables of interest. They increase our general understanding of scientific processes and provide the insights needed to develop new theories and ask deeper questions.

When conducting a designed experiment, there are variables that a researcher can control. These variables need to be set at certain levels. For example, ambient temperature can be such a variable. As another example, in a longitudinal study, an experimenter may be able to select the times at which measurements are to be made on an individual. If a variable is not of primary interest for the study, then it could be kept constant during the study. But if it is of interest, then the experimenter may want to select different levels for the variables for different measurements to get a better understanding of the role of these variables.

The collection of choices for the settings of the controllable variables forms the design for the experiment. Some designs are better than others, and which one is best depends on such things as the model for the data and the objectives of the experiment. It is easier to address this question for some models (linear models) than for others (generalized linear models and nonlinear models). This project focused on the latter group of models. It is also easier to address this question for independent data than for dependent data. This project focused on the latter, but also made a link between results for independent data and dependent data. Finally, it is easier to address this question if there is only variable for which the settings need to be determined. This project focused on having multiple variables, some quantitative and others qualitative, that can be varied by the experimenter.

In this project we developed theoretical results and computational tools to identify so called locally optimal designs for a variety of scenarios. This includes designs for discrete choice experiments, which are often used to study consumer product preferences. It also includes designs for longitudinal studies, which are often used to study the effect of a drug or treatment over time. And it includes event-related fMRI studies, in which the design consists of a sequence of tasks for a subject in a scanner. In some of these scenarios the data are naturally dependent, such as in a longitudinal study. We also considered scenarios in which the experimenter could vary multiple quantitative and qualitative variables. We developed a better understanding of the structure of optimal designs in all of these settings. Moreover, the results can be used as benchmarks to compare other designs to.

In searching for optimal designs, there are many criteria that one could consider. Some of the traditional criteria include D-optimality, A-optimality, and others. In some scenarios we were able to obtain results that are more general. It is based on what is known as complete class results. The idea is that, rather than identifying a single design that is optimal under a specific criterion, one identifies a relatively small class of designs that is guaranteed to contain the optimal designs under many criteria. This can be useful in terms of reducing computational efforts needed to find an optimal design; for any given optimality criterion to which the complete class applies, one only needs to search for an optimal design within this small class.

Besides the intellectual merit of the project?s outcomes, as described above, the potential for broader impact is enormous, simply because experiments as described above are conducted in medical research, public health research, marketing research, and many other areas.

The project also contributed significantly to the training of PhD students and a postdoc. As many as seven current or former PhD students of the PI contributed to the project, as well as one former postdoc. Four of these eight individuals are female, so that the project also contributed to the training of members of this underrepresented group.

Results from the work were widely disseminated through publications in professional journals and through many invited presentations at national and international conferences and at seminars at other universities.
